In the video for "I'm a princess," there is an almost-constant border around part or all of the scenes. Some things, such as a few lyrics, the dream falling from the ceiling, the "what an interesting song" part where the guy is spinning on the bracket, etc., are not confined to the border. The thickness of the border, as well as its color, also changes throughout the video. Then when the video of you starts to play, it seems like you are referring to the border around you as a door, and these doors start doing some really interesting things and at some points there are many doors on screen, and even doors within doors. At 2:57 you can even see one of these doors forming around two other doors of you playing music. Then at 3:13, all of the scene with the set (really the whole video so far) goes through ANOTHER door (this time an actual door) and into your room, which has no borderdoor around it until the ceiling "goes."

This seems super intentional but I'm not quite sure what the border/door signifies in the context of this songvideo. My initial theory is that the border represents a view into a dream, and that whatever escapes that dream view is somehow escaping the dreamscape. But, like I said, I'm not sure.

it represents "i'm in way over my head and i have no idea how to finish this video in my lifetime and make it actually the way i want it, so i'm fucked. and i just realized borders make most things look better, so that is somewhat of a liferaft for me in this situation"
Regardless, I love it and think it/you are amazing.

If you were to write something out that was, for example, in C mixo... Would you just make the key sig as C major and flat the B's whenever they come up? Or would you put the Bb on the key sig and possibly lead to some confusion as to if the song is in Fmaj instead?

as common as mixolydian and dorian seem to be, for the root key of songs, still key signatures tend to be immediately interpreted as ionian or aeolian. This seems kind of disappointing, but, to be fair, it is important to have an obvious way to tell someone what the real root key of a song is. Weirdly, most of the time, the key signature seems to be used to display this info AS IF it were ionian or aeolian, and then rudely use accidentals all the time. which feels kind of sad/wrong, but it happens. But actually, if you write 'C mixolydian' on the top of the page and then do it with a 1 flat key signature, i don't think anyone will mind

im best friends with my own front door activates this part of my brain i can never reach. it's amazing. it's the bent key that somehow unlocks the safe to gold and crack. specifically talking about 1:40 to the end, all the lines connect together so perfectlyHOW WAS THIS MASTERPIECE MADE. i want the full backstory. maybe some lines from the timestamp i said would do..

this is exactly what happened. all my life i've struggled with the reality that it takes me much much much longer than i wish it takes, to produce anything. years go by and i'm fighting to reach a reasonable pace, and never seem to succeed. well, one day i suddenly snapped, took a desperate walk outside, got angry and screamed at the sky a little (in my mind), and just said '2 weeks or die trying'. the thing is, i'm sure i've tried saying this before, but sometimes the stars align and it works. so the first part of doing any song is song selection. i go through my list of songs, which have a writing % completion of anywhere from .1% to 100%. and i have to choose one. this is normally almost impossible for me, and to do it right, i have to spend many days on it. i went through maybe 50% of the list, and it felt like none of them were really working for me at the time, and i felt a bit pressured to do it quickly (because of the 2 week challenge i was doing), and so in a snap decision, i said 'what song do i WISH i was doing', and i was able to trick myself into imagining the first line. so that was cool, felt like i was off to a roaring start, and then suddenly a day went by and i hadn't made it out of the 'box' of that melody/chord sequence. in other words, i had maybe the first 6 lines, which, as you can hear, are all within the same exact musical figure. but what scared me most was that i had spent way too long and only come up with a few seconds. and i knew this was no way to beat the 2 week challenge. so essentially i realized that i had to finish the writing in 4 hours. so basically a ruthless burst of paranoid speed had to kick in. you can probably hear the brute force, desperation, and then attempts to deal with it, in the 'bad sign' part, and 'not gonna happen' part. basically i've hurled myself off the edge, into whatever comes next, before having earthly idea what would actually come next. so in that sense i was almost improvising (in the writing). To be clear, i'm talking about the writing, which is done entirely before the recording. so i'm not saying i improvised the song during recording. i always write the song first. but during the writing process it felt a bit like improvising because i had to write it so fast. So the next few sections sort of have their ups and downs, for better or for worse, because at this point i've convinced myself that there's no turning back, i have to just run, because there's no time. And inevitably, if you are able to truly adopt this attitude, it eventually finds its feet. and that seems to happen when it lands on the outvamp, and these last 16 bars seem to be an outpouring of the exact emotions i was dealing with, in the circumstances of the 2 week challenge and all the desperation leading up to it, and how i was dealing with it

I've come to the point where i think i know most chord progresion and harmony structures in existence. This also applies to melodies andrythms. I've listened to so much music in the last two years that i think i know way to much in comparison to what i knew before. This could seem like a good thing but in fact all the music now just sounds empty. During the last two years i used to get excited when i heard a key change or an original harmonic structure, i used to listen to music all day long and know i feel like i reached the bottom and there isn't much more i can learn. I know i still can but 80% of the total is gone and i no longer enjoy music the same way I did before, ever since december that hardly any song got stuck in my head which it used to be something normal in my everyday life, I was always with songs in my head. The same happens with piano improvisation. I feel like if i no longer have anything to play or listen and I'm starting to l ose interest in music in general. What should I do? I don't want to separate music from me. Have you ever felt this way? If so, what did you do?

the skills/learning aspect of music was fun for me, but i've always been more deeply drawn to the 'voodoo' aspect of music. there's no end to the different levels of voodoo you can learn to do with music. and having technical skills is certainly a great starting place to explore that. But, if you are more attracted to the skills/learning aspect, there are many many more fields that i think would interest you a lot. from sports, to games, computers, quantum mechanics, and beyond. someone's gonna have to invent teleportation at some point
